questions.text: 1. Given below is the microscopic appearance of a liver biopsy section of a male patient. Which of the following is not usually seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Choreoathetosis is not a consequence of hemochromatosis. 

The liver biopsy section stained with Perl's Prussian Blue shows blue-stained hepatocyte iron accumulation which is suggestive of hereditary hemochromatosis. Choreoathetosis is a movement disorder seen in Wilson's disease due to neurological involvement, not in hemochromatosis. 

Hemochromatosis, which is an autosomal recessive condition, is caused by excessive iron absorption, most of which is deposited in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas, followed by the heart, joints, and endocrine organs.

The following features are seen in hemochromatosis :

* Micronodular cirrhosis

* Diabetes mellitus

* Abnormal skin pigmentation

* Koilonychia 

* Arthropathy

* Hypogonadism( amenorrhea in females, impotence and loss of libido in the male) 

* Congestive cardiac failure

* Chondrocalcinosis or pseudogout

When hemochromatosis results from an inherited disorder, it is referred to as hereditary hemochromatosis. When accumulation occurs as a consequence of parenteral administration of iron it is called secondary hemochromatosis. The adult form of hemochromatosis is almost always caused by mutations of HFE; mutation of TFR2 is far less common.

The main regulator of iron absorption is the protein hepcidin, encoded by the HAMP gene and secreted by the liver.

Other proteins involved in iron metabolism that regulate hepcidin levels include-

* Hemojuvelin (HJV)

* Transferrin receptor 2 (TFR2)

* HFE, product of the hemochromatosis gene.

Decreased hepcidin synthesis has a central role in the pathogenesis of hemochromatosis.

The therapy of hemochromatosis involves the removal of the excess body iron, best accomplished by weekly or twice-weekly phlebotomy of 500 mL (200–250 mg of iron). Chelating agents such as desferoxamine, when given parenterally, remove 10–20 mg of iron per day, which is much less than that mobilized by once-weekly phlebotomy.

Death may result from cirrhosis or cardiac disease. A significant cause of death is hepatocellular carcinomas.

questions.text: 2. A 27-year-old male patient, with a history of upper respiratory tract infection, presents with rapidly progressing, symmetric, ascending paralysis since 7 days. The knee jerk reflex is absent bilaterally. Investigations show elevated CSF protein levels. Which of the following is affected by this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of progressive, ascending, symmetrical weakness, following a respiratory infection is suggestive of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). It is an immune-mediated disease, where autoimmune cells attack the myelin proteins of the peripheral nervous system. 

GBS is caused by an immune response and/or antibodies produced against external antigens (e.g. Campylobacter jejuni, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, and human herpesvirus [HHV]) introduced by infections  or by vaccines such as influenza vaccine. These autoantibodies target similar proteins present in the person's nervous tissue—a phenomenon called molecular mimicry.

GBS manifests as a rapidly evolving motor paralysis with areflexia (or hyporeflexia), with or without sensory disturbance. It is an ascending paralysis that affects the lower limbs more than the upper limbs. It can also affect the cranial nerves, leading to features of bulbar paralysis like difficulty articulating words and excessive drooling.

Glia (Greek: glue) are cells that help in communication within the CNS. They are classified into 2 types according to their sizes—microglia and macroglia. Macroglia are of 3 types—astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, and Schwann cells.

Schwann cells and oligodendrocytes are responsible for myelin formation around the axons of the peripheral nerves and nerves in the brain and spinal cord respectively. Myelin protein zero (P0) and hydrophobic protein PMP22 are components of the myelin sheath in the peripheral nervous system. They are affected in different conditions: 

* Multiple sclerosis - Patchy destruction of the myelin sheath in the central nervous system

* Guillain-Barre syndrome - Autoimmune destruction of myelin protein genes (P0 and PMP22)

* Charcot-Marrie-Tooth disease - Mutations in the myelin protein genes (P0 and PMP22) causing disruption of myelin and axonal degeneration.

Pearl PM1628: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

* B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.

* Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM

* The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.

* Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.

* The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.

* These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

questions.text: 3. A 68-year-old male came to the physician with complaints of chronic back pain and easy fatigability. He has also been treated twice for urinary tract infections in the last 3 months. An x-ray of his skull is shown below. Which of the following laboratory parameters is consistent with this diagnosis?

choices.text: Hypercalcemia, high alkaline phosphatase and normal ESR
Hypercalcemia, high alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR
Hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, normal ESR
Hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the skull radiograph showing punched-out lesions suggest multiple myeloma. Hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, and elevated ESR are the laboratory parameters consistent with a diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. Bone pain is the most common symptom of multiple myeloma. Tumor cells release osteoclast activating factors (OAFs), which increased osteoclast activity and accelerated bone destruction.

Furthermore, there is suppression of osteoblast activity to form new bone. Lysis of the bone leads to hypercalcemia. Patients with multiple myeloma also have an increased susceptibility to infections because of diffuse hypogammaglobulinemia (decreased production and increased destruction) of normal antibodies. 

Other important features of multiple myeloma include: 

* Renal failure

* Normocytic and normochromic anemia

* Hyperviscosity syndromes

* Elevated ESR

* Normal alkaline phosphatase due to suppression of osteoblast activity.

* Serum protein electrophoresis shows the presence of monoclonal protein

* Urinalysis shows free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence-Jones proteins)

Diagnostic Criteria for Multiple Myeloma include: 

Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥10% (or) biopsy-proven bony or extramedullary plasmacytoma

plus

Any one or more of the following myeloma-defining events:

* Evidence of end-organ damage attributable to the underlying plasma cell proliferative disorder, specifically: (CRAB features)

* Hypercalcemia: Serum calcium level >1 mg/dL higher than the upper limit of normal or >11 mg/dL

* Renal insufficiency: Serum creatinine >2 mg/dL

* Anemia: Hemoglobin level of >2 g/dL below the lowest limit of normal, or Hb <10 g/dL

* Bone lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions on radiography, computed tomography (CT), or positron emission tomography (PET).

* Any one or more of the following biomarkers of malignancy:

* Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥ 60%

* Serum involved / uninvolved free light-chain ratio of 100 or greater.

* >1 focal lesion on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

* Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)

* Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)

* Metastasis

* Lymphoma

* Tuberculosis 

* Osteomyelitis 

* Radiation

questions.text: 4. A 45-year- old labourer presented to the emergency with weakness in the right side of the body and slurred speech. His history showed that he followed a strict vegetarian diet. O/E he was afebrile, his BP was 160/100 mm Hg, and HR was 110/min. Routine investigations were normal except for raised homocysteine levels. Which of the following deficiencies is not responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Niacin deficiency does not cause hyperhomocysteinemia as given in the above clinical scenario.

All the following vitamin deficiencies - pyridoxine (Vitamin B6), folic acid, and cobalamin (B12) can cause hyperhomocysteinemia, which can lead to stroke, as given in the clinical scenario.

Vitamin B6 serves as the cofactor for the enzyme cystathionine-β-synthase, while vitamin B12 is necessary for methionine synthase function, enabling the remethylation of homocysteine to methionine. A deficiency of vitamin B12 leads to the failure in the conversion of methyl tetrahydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate, causing folate to accumulate in the form of methyl tetrahydrofolate and resulting in a functional folate deficiency.



Classic homocystinuria is a metabolic disorder of methionine metabolism due to cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency. It is an autosomal recessive condition.

Cystathionine beta-synthase is a pyridoxal phosphate-dependent enzyme that condenses homocysteine with serine to form cystathionine. The absence of this enzyme will cause cysteine deficiency, hence cysteine needs to be supplemented in the diet.

Clinical features: Affected children are initially asymptomatic, with ectopia lentis typically observed after 3 years of age. They may experience intellectual disability as well as psychiatric and behavioural disorders. Additionally, thromboembolic episodes can occur, and skeletal abnormalities resembling those of Marfan syndrome are often present, resulting in individuals who are tall and thin with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly (slender fingers).

Elevations of both methionine and homocysteine in body fluids are the diagnostic laboratory findings. The diagnosis is established by molecular analysis of cystathionine β-synthase (CBS) or by assay of the enzyme in cultured fibroblasts, phytohemagglutinin-stimulated lymphocytes, or liver biopsy specimens. Treatment includes restriction of methionine intake and supplementation with cysteine, betaine, vitamins B6, B12, and folate.

Methionine supplementation is required in non-classical homocystinuria. It is due to impaired re-methylation of homocysteine to methionine. This can be caused by defective methionine synthase or reduced availability of two essential cofactors, 5-methyltetrahydrofolate and methylcobalamin.

Elevated homocysteine levels with low levels of methionine will be seen. Treatment includes methionine supplementation and administration of methyl folate, hydroxocobalamin, and betaine.

Pearl PM2304: Homocystinuria



The concept for treatment:

* Since homocysteine is produced from methionine, decreased dietary intake of methionine decreases the formation of homocysteine.

* As the end product of this cycle is cysteine, increased dietary intake of cysteine will decrease the conversion of methionine to homocysteine through negative feedback.

questions.text: 5. A 40-year-old woman presents with a sudden loss of vision in both eyes that occurred after a stressful argument with her boss. On examination, her visual acuity is recorded as 6/6 in each eye, and her pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. There are no abnormalities found on ophthalmic examination or in other neurological evaluations. When asked to follow a moving object or identify visual stimuli, she demonstrates inconsistent performance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette given is conversion disorder /functional neurologic symptom disorder.

Conversion disorder is a condition with symptoms or deficits that involve voluntary motor or sensory functions. Though it points to an underlying medical condition, in reality, it arises due to psychological factors. The symptoms are not intentionally produced and the gain obtained is primarily psychological. 

It can be associated with depressive disorders, anxiety disorders, personality disorders, and somatization disorders. Paralysis, blindness, and mutism are the most frequently seen conversion disorder symptoms. Anaesthesia and paresthesia of the extremities, abnormal movements, and gait disturbance are the other features commonly seen. 

Conversion disorder usually resolves spontaneously. Insight-oriented or behavioural therapy is also helpful. Hypnosis and anxiolytics are used in some cases. 

Other options: 

Option B: Catatonia is a condition seen in advanced primary mood or psychotic illnesses. Some conditions that can cause catatonia include head trauma, encephalitis, and hepatic encephalopathy. Some medications such as corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, or antipsychotics can also result in the condition. Some clinical features include grimacing, mutism, echolalia, stupor, and posturing.

Option C: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO), especially in its ischemic form, usually presents with severe visual loss, marked retinal haemorrhages, cotton wool spots, optic disc oedema, and a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), often accompanied by detectable abnormalities on ophthalmic examination. However, this patient has normal visual acuity, normal pupillary reactions, and no detectable abnormalities on ophthalmic or neurological exams, making CRVO an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

Option D: Eales' disease, common in young Asian males, features recurrent vitreous haemorrhage and retinal neovascularization due to peripheral retinal vein inflammation. It presents with a reddish vitreous mass and can lead to vision loss and complications like retinal detachment. However, it is less likely here due to the patient’s demographics and absence of characteristic findings.

Pearl PM0377: Conversion Disorder

Conversion disorder: Also called functional neurological symptom disorder.

Common presenting symptoms:

* Weakness and/or paralysis

* Non-epileptic seizures

* Movement disorders

* Speech or visual impairment like mutism or blindness

* Swallowing difficulty

* Sensory disturbances

* Cognitive symptoms

Diagnostic criteria:

* Symptoms of altered neurological function-voluntary motor or sensory

* Often precipitated by a psychological stressor (the temporal relationship between stressor and symptoms is present)

* Not feigned or intentionally produced (as in factitious disorder or malingering)

* Findings incompatible with a recognized neurological condition

* Symptoms cause significant social or occupational impairment

Other important features:

* Primary gain - Unconscious relief from stress as the focus of the patient shifts to the symptoms.

* Secondary gain - Attention gained by the patient (from bystanders) as a result of the symptoms.

* La-belle indifference - refers to an absence of concern towards one’s problem despite severe disability

* Astasia abasia - Wildly ataxic, staggering gait accompanied by irregular, jerky truncal movements, thrashing and waving arm movements

Management options:

* First-line: Education and self-help technique

* Second-line: Cognitive-behavioral therapy

* Physical therapy for motor symptoms

questions.text: 6. An elderly lady complains of recurrent right-sided headaches, nonspecific shoulder pain, and jaw pain on chewing for 6 months. ESR is 107mm/hr. Which of the following features would be characteristically seen in a biopsy specimen obtained from her?

choices.text: Multinucleated cells in the arterial intima and media
Eosinophils and neutrophils in the arterial intima and media
Lymphocytes and plasma cells in the arterial adventitia
Fibrinoid necrosis of the arterial wall

questions.solution:
This patient with recurrent headaches, jaw claudication and non specific shoulder pain (likely polymyalgia rheumatica) with an elevated ESR most likely has giant cell arteritis. The presence of multinucleated cells, or giant cells in the arterial intima and media is the most suggestive biopsy feature of Giant cell arteritis (GCA). 

GCA is a chronic, large-vessel vasculitis that commonly affects the temporal arteries, but can also involve the aorta, its branches, and the ophthalmic arteries. It is the most common vasculitis in adults over 50 years.

Histopathology also shows panarteritis with infiltration of inflammatory mononuclear cells with giant cell formation. Intimal thickening and fragmentation of the internal elastic lamina are also seen (black arrow). Multinucleated giant cells are large cells with multiple nuclei that are formed by the fusion of macrophages (yellow arrow). They are a hallmark of GCA and are not typically seen in other types of vasculitis.



There is thickening and narrowing of the artery, resulting in thrombosis, ischemia or aneurysms. Symptoms include headache, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, visual disturbances, fever, fatigue, and weight loss. It is also associated with mononeuritis multiplex; peripheral neuropathy in two or more separate nerve areas. A dreaded complication is ischemic optic neuropathy, which can lead to sudden blindness. 

Elevated ESR and anaemia are characteristic laboratory findings. Raised liver enzymes, especially alkaline phosphatase are common. Levels of IgG and complement may be raised. GCA is treated with corticosteroids.

Other options:

Option B: Eosinophils and neutrophils can be seen in Churg-Strauss syndrome and Polyarteritis Nodosa. 

Option C: Lymphocytes and plasma cells are seen in many types of inflammation, including GCA, but are not specific.

Option D: Fibrinoid necrosis of the arterial wall can be seen in GCA, but is also seen in Polyarteritis Nodosa.

questions.text: 7. An elderly patient who works in a mining industry presented to the physician with complaints of breathlessness which has increased for the past 3 months. The chest radiograph was done and it showed the presence of ground-glass appearance. Pulmonary function tests showed a decrease in the lung volumes and a normal FEV1/FVC. Which of the following curves in the graph denotes the lung compliance in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of asbestosis with a restrictive pattern in pulmonary function tests. Therefore, it is likely to show a decreased lung compliance which is depicted by curve 1 in the graph.

The extent to which the lungs will expand for each unit increase in transpulmonary pressure is called lung compliance. The total compliance of both lungs together in the normal adult averages about 200 ml of air/cm H2O transpulmonary pressure.

* Curve 2 in the graph represents normal compliance.

* The curve is shifted downwards (curve 1) in the case of decreased compliance. Eg. pulmonary edema, interstitial pulmonary fibrosis.

* The curve is shifted upwards and to the left (curves 3 and 4) in the case of increased compliance. Eg. emphysema.



Pearl PM0087: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

* Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance

* For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume

* Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation

* If the surface tension is more, compliance is less

* Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

* Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.

* Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.

* If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.

* Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

* Pulmonary emphysema

* Normal aging lung

questions.text: 8. A 56-year-old male is brought with complaints of crushing chest pain. On auscultation, crackles are heard on respiration and ST elevation is seen on ECG. He was told 2 days ago that he had terminal pancreatic cancer. Imaging findings are shown below. What is the likely mechanism of his current disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, one of the mechanisms for which is microcirculation spasms secondary to catecholamine surge.  

The given ventriculogram shows apical dilatation with basal hypercontraction of the heart. This, coupled with sudden chest pain with pulmonary edema(crackles on respiration) with ECG changes mimicking a myocardial infarction in the setting of recent stressful news, indicates Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. It is characterized by transient myocardial stunning from microcirculation spasms due to a catecholamine surge during stress. 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is also called broken heart syndrome, apical ballooning syndrome, or stress-induced cardiomyopathy. It is usually seen in middle-aged women. The patients may present with pulmonary edema, hypotension, and chest pain.

Echocardiography reveals apical dilatation with basal hypercontraction of the heart, resembling a takotsubo (pot for catching octopus). The ECG changes can mimic those of myocardial infarction. Therefore, coronary angiography may be needed to rule out coronary occlusion. 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is a self-limiting disorder, resolving within days to weeks. The prognosis is generally good.

The image below shows left ventriculography during systole showing apical ballooning, resembling the takotsubo pot.

questions.text: 9. A 30-year-old man, status post craniotomy for a subdural hematoma developed 2 episodes of new-onset seizures. His volume status is represented by the following Darrow-Yannet diagram. Which of the following drugs can be used for the management of his condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of a patient with new-onset seizures post craniotomy and Darrow Yannet diagram showing reduced plasma osmolality and increased volume of ECF and ICF is suggestive of SIADH - Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Production. Conivaptan is the best-suited drug for the management of this condition.

Darrow Yannet diagrams depict the change in plasma osmolarity and plasma volume in various conditions. The illustration given below shows the Darrow-Yannet diagram in various conditions.



SIADH is characterized by excess production of ADH irrespective of serum osmolality, which can occur due to head trauma, postoperatively, drug-induced, malignancies, etc. Excess reabsorption of free water from the collecting duct without solute reabsorption results in excess sodium loss in urine and the production of concentrated urine.

Clinically, the patient remains Euvolemic because the excess fluid is redistributed proportionately in the ECF & ICF. (Euvolemic hyponatremia). Bartter and Schwartz's criteria can be used to diagnose SIADH.

Management of SIADH: In an acute symptomatic setting, 3% NaCl infusion is recommended at a rate of 1% per hour to gradually raise serum sodium levels, targeting 130 mEq/L. In addition, aquaretic agents can be used, such as Conivaptan, a combined V1a/V2 antagonist available for IV administration, or Tolvaptan, an oral V2 antagonist suited for short-term use.

For the management of chronic SIADH, the preferred approach is fluid restriction, limiting total fluid intake to less than the combined urinary and insensible losses. Oral Tolvaptan is an appropriate choice for longer-term management, particularly when fluid restriction alone is insufficient to maintain sodium balance.

Other options:

Option A: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that may exacerbate the hyponatremia of SIADH as it induces solute & water loss.

Option C. Carbamazepine is an antiepileptic agent that itself causes SIADH and can worsen the seizures

Option D. Fludrocortisone, although it promotes reabsorption of sodium from the renal tubules, is more useful in a setting of hypovolemia, as in Cerebral salt wasting syndrome.

questions.text: 10. A 55-year-old female patient presents with dry eyes, dry mouth, and difficulty in swallowing solid food. Examination reveals enlargement of parotid glands. Laboratory examination shows the presence of both SS-A and SS-B antibodies. The histopathological image of the salivary gland is given below. She is at high risk for developing ______.
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a 55-year-old female patient with dry eyes, dry mouth, difficulty swallowing solid food, and the findings such as enlarged parotid gland, and antibodies positive for SS-A and SS-B is Sjogren's syndrome. The histopathology shows focal lymphoplasmacytic infiltration in the salivary gland. She is at high risk for the development of marginal zone lymphoma.

Sjögren's syndrome is a chronic disease wherein the lacrimal and salivary glands undergo immunologically-mediated destruction. This leads to the characteristic features of dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia). It can manifest as primary or secondary.

Primary is an isolated form known as sicca syndrome. It is characterized by decreased tears and saliva. The salivary glands and lacrimal glands get infiltrated with lymphocytes and undergo fibrosis. The secondary form is associated with other autoimmune disorders. 

Clinically, it is more common in women between 50-60 years. They present with a blurring of vision, burning, itching of the eyes, difficulty swallowing solid foods, dryness of the buccal mucosa, and parotid gland enlargement. 

Antibodies directed against two ribonucleoprotein antigens -SS-A (Ro) and SS-B (La) are detected in almost all patients with Sjogren's syndrome. Rheumatoid factor is seen in about 75% of the patients. ANA is also often detected on immunofluorescence assay. A labial biopsy is useful and histology of salivary glands shows lymphocytic infiltration. 

Patients are at high risk for the development of marginal zone lymphoma that arises in the presence of chronic lymphocytic inflammation.

Other options -

Option A: Adult T-Cell Leukemia/Lymphoma - It is observed in adults infected by human T-cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1). It is characterized by skin lesions, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, peripheral blood lymphocytosis, and hypercalcemia. Peripheral smear shows cells with multilobulated nuclei (“cloverleaf” or “flower” cells). It is a rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to 1 year.

Option B: Mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. It is more common in middle-aged men and people with darker skin. MF may present as dermatitis or eczema for a few years before progressing to the classical presentation of patches and plaques as shown in the image above. The most common sites involved are the trunk, limbs, breasts, and buttocks. The lesions may present with pruritus or be asymptomatic. As it progresses, the patient may develop, ulceration and pain or even widespread erythroderma. 

Option C: Sezary syndrome is most often seen as a progression of mycosis fungoides. Sezary syndrome is defined by the following clinical triad:

* Erythroderma

* Peripheral lymphadenopathy

* Atypical circulating mononuclear cells

The extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are as follows:

* Arthralgia or arthritis - It is the most common extraglandular manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jacoud’s arthropathy

* Raynaud’s phenomenon

* Extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue (MALToma).

questions.text: 11. A 65-year-old female patient complains of bilateral lower limb pain described as burning. She is diabetic and has not been compliant with medications. Physical examination shows that the pain is distributed in a stocking-like pattern bilaterally. Her HbA1C is measured to be 8.5%. Which of the following is a first-line drug for the management of the patient's pain?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of a diagnosis of diabetic neuropathy. Duloxetine is a serotonin–norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) and is one of the first-line drugs used in the treatment of painful diabetic neuropathy. 

This patient with uncontrolled diabetes suggested by her elevated HbA1C and glove-stocking pattern of pain distribution, is highly suggestive of diabetic neuropathy. The pain is commonly characterized as burning pain or tingling. 

Treatment of painful sensory neuropathies:

 First-line

* Duloxetine

* Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline, nortriptyline)

* Gabapentin, Pregabalin

* Venlafaxine

Second Line

* Carbamazepine

* Phenytoin

* Tramadol

* Tapentadol

Optimal glucose control is considered the cornerstone for the treatment of diabetes and its complications. Intensive glucose control has been shown to prevent the development of peripheral neuropathy.

 Types of diabetic neuropathy

* Distal symmetric sensory or sensorimotor polyneuropathy

* Most common type

* Begins at the toes and slowly moves proximally

* Presents as tingling, burning, or deep aching pain.

* Commonly presents in a glove and stocking distribution

* Autonomic neuropathy Presents as abnormal sweating, GI abnormalities, dry eyes and mouth, pupillary abnormalities, dysfunctional thermoregulation, cardiac arrhythmias, postural hypotension, etc.

* Diabetic radiculoplexus neuropathy (diabetic amyotrophy or Bruns-Garland Syndrome)

* Presents as low back/ hip/ thigh pain

* Commonly associated with weight loss

The image below shows the glove-stocking distribution of pain.

* Polyradiculopathy or plexopathy due to diabetes mellitus

questions.text: 12. An elderly man suffered a disc prolapse while lifting a heavy box, leading to nerve injury. This resulted in the development of lower limb muscle weakness. Which of the following features would be associated with this type of muscle weakness?
questions.solution:
Lumbar disc prolapse/ spondylolisthesis will result in a lower motor neuron type of muscle weakness in the distribution of the involved nerve root. Lower motor neuron weakness is associated with fasciculations in the affected muscles.

Lower motor neuron weakness (LMN) refers to muscle weakness due to injury to either the brain stem motor nuclei, anterior horn cells of the spinal cord, or peripheral motor neuron axons. When the motor unit is damaged, it can result in spontaneous firing of the nerve, leading to fasciculations in the muscles supplied by it. This presents as a muscle twitch that can be seen or palpated.

LMN disease is also associated with flaccid paralysis and decreased muscle tone. There can also be significant wasting and atrophy of the muscles involved, along with hyporeflexia. 

In contrast to this, upper motor neuron disease (UMN) will show spastic paralysis, hyperactive reflexes, and no signs of fasciculation. They may show some disuse atrophy over time, but this is not as significant as that seen in lower motor neuron disease.

Lumbar disc prolapse can result in damage to lumbar nerve roots. Since these arise from the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord, the muscle weakness involved will be an LMN type of weakness and will show the above-mentioned symptoms and signs.

Other options-

Option (A): Muscle hypertrophy will not be seen in any type of motor neuron injury. Significant atrophy can be seen in LMN lesions, while disuse atrophy over time can be seen with UMN lesions.

Option (C): Spasticity is seen in UMN lesions. It presents as an increase in muscle tone.

Option (D): Hyperreflexia is a feature of UMN nerve injury. There may be an acute decrease in reflexes, but this is normally followed by hyperreflexia. LMN lesions, on the other hand, will present with depressed reflexes.

Upper motor neuron typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons

Lower motor neurons are those whose axons terminate on skeletal muscles

Little or no muscle wasting → weakness of relatively large group of muscles

Muscle atrophy → muscle weakness of an individual and specific muscle

questions.text: 13. A 60-year-old man who underwent a coronary artery bypass 6 days ago developed fever and productive cough with purulent, blood-tinged sputum. His chest X-ray and sputum culture on Cetrimide agar are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
This patient has developed Late-onset hospital-acquired pneumonia (> 5 days). The chest-Xray shows wedge-shaped opacity involving the right middle lobe, suggestive of bacterial pneumonia. Culture shows the growth of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in Cetrimide agar with colonies showing  greenish-yellow fluorescein pigment.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include Pyorubin (Red), Pyomelanin (Brown).

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

* Malignant otitis externa in diabetics

* Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis

* Wound infection and sepsis in burns

* Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a common type of folliculitis, which causes inflammation of hair follicles

* Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric disease, sepsis with invasive disease.

* Ecthyma gangrenosum

Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or nosocomial pneumonia is a lower respiratory infection that presents clinically 2 or more days after hospitalization and was not there at the time of admission.

* Early-onset HAP (occurring within 4-5 days) is most commonly caused by S. aureus, P. aeruginosa, Enterobacter species, K pneumoniae, Legionella pneumophila

* Late-onset HAP (> 5 days) is usually caused by Gram-negative bacteria (ex: Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Klebsiella spp, and Acinetobacter baumannii), S. aureus, and anaerobes.

Other options:

* Klebsiella species has no particular selective medium and is usually differentiated through biochemical reactions

* Staphylococcus aureus is selectively cultured in Mannitol salt agar, Ludlam's medium and Salt milk agar. Golden-yellow S. aureus colonies is given below.



Legionella pneumophila causes community-acquired pneumonia and early-onset hospital-acquired pneumonia and grows selectively on BCYE (Buffered charcoal yeast extract agar) medium. It is as shown below.

questions.text: 14. During a preoperative anesthetic evaluation, pharmacologic stress echocardiography is being undertaken for a patient with chronic pulmonary disease. Which of the following is the most preferred agent used for inducing pharmacological stress in this patient?
questions.solution:
Dobutamine is the most preferred agent among the given drugs for the induction of pharmacological stress in a patient with chronic pulmonary disease.

Dobutamine is a potent β-receptor agonist used for stress testing. It increases myocardial oxygen demand by increasing contractility, heart rate, and blood pressure in a similar manner as exercise. Dobutamine stress testing is the preferred choice for the assessment of myocardial viability and is generally used as an alternative to vasodilator stress in patients with chronic pulmonary disease, where vasodilators are contraindicated.  

Cardiac stress testing is performed in patients with known or suspected coronary artery disease. It is also done for preoperative CVS monitoring in a patient with risk factors for myocardial infarction. Generally, exercise stress testing is preferred because it provides information on functional capacity, exercise tolerance, and symptom provocation. However, some patients undergo pharmacologic stress testing. Indications for pharmacologic stress testing include: 

* Unstable angina

* Inability to exercise

* History of uncontrolled heart failure at risk for deterioration

* Poorly controlled blood pressure

* History of aortic stenosis

* Recent myocardial infarction

* Acute pulmonary embolism

* Acute pericarditis or myocarditis

* Severe pulmonary hypertension

* Chronic pulmonary disease

Vasodilators are the most commonly used pharmacologic stressors for myocardial perfusion imaging. Vasodilator stress acts by increasing and diverting blood flow to the non-diseased blood vessels so that the diseased vessels can be visualized clearly. It is brought about by drugs such as adenosine, dipyridamole, and regadenoson.

Adenosine and dipyridamole must be completely avoided in chronic pulmonary disease due to the high risk of inducing bronchospasm in such patients. Regadenson could exacerbate symptoms hence must be used with relative caution. Due to this, dobutamine is the most preferred agent.

questions.text: 15. A young man presents to the hospital with complaints of profuse diarrhea for the past 2 days. He says that he had been to Goa and had tried seafood and shellfish. There is no fever. He says that the stool appears watery and gray. The result of a test is shown in the image below. What is the antibiotic of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the test are suggestive of cholera infection, for which the antibiotic of choice among the given options is Erythromycin.

The test shown in the above image is the String test performed to identify the colonies of Vibrio cholerae. Erythromycin and azithromycin are the antibiotics of choice in this patient.

Cholera is a diarrheal disease caused by Vibrio cholerae serogroup O1 or O139. It is commonly acquired by eating contaminated water and shellfish. The incubation period is around 24- 48 hours. 

Patients may be asymptomatic or have only mild diarrhea. Others present with the sudden onset of explosive and life-threatening diarrhea (cholera gravis). They usually complain of sudden onset of painless watery diarrhea which can become voluminous. It is associated with vomiting. Fever is usually absent. 

The stool has a characteristic appearance. It appears gray, slightly cloudy fluid with flecks of mucus, no blood, and has a fishy odor. It has been called a “rice-water” stool because it resembles the water in which rice has been washed.

The selective media of the organism is as taurocholate–tellurite–gelatin (TTG) agar or thiosulfate–citrate–bile salts–sucrose (TCBS) agar.

Treatment involves rehydration with oral rehydration solution or ringer's lactate. Erythromycin and azithromycin are the antibiotic agents of choice.

Other options:

Option A- Ciprofloxacin is used in the treatment of shigellosis. The patient may have a fever, abdominal cramps, and bloody mucopurulent stools.

Option C- Streptomycin is used in the treatment of brucellosis. It is a zoonotic disease and is caused by exposure to infected animals or their products. It can be due to ingestion, inhalation, or mucosal or percutaneous exposure. It presents as a fever with profuse sweating, especially at night.

Option D- Ceftriaxone is used in the treatment of enteric fever. It presents as headache, chills, malaise, arthralgia, abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. On examination, they may have a faint, salmon-coloured, blanching, maculopapular rash located primarily on the trunk and hepatosplenomegaly.

questions.text: 16. A 36-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a history of crampy abdominal pain for the last 6 months. The pain is exacerbated by stress and meals and relieved by defaecation. For the last 4 months she had episodes of decreased frequency of stools. The stool is pellet-shaped, of small-volume and hard and she frequently also has abdominal bloating and flatulence. She experienced these episodes for at least 1 or 2 days every week for last 4 months. She has had no improvement with lifestyle modification and dietary supplements and her physician starts her on medication for this condition. Which of the following is a possible mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Centrally acting, mu opioid receptor agonist

questions.solution:
The given clinical complex is suggestive of constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome. The patient has probably been started on lubiprostone, which is a chloride channel activator.

The ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS  must be fulfilled for the last 3 months with symptom onset at least 6 months before diagnosis.

The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

Features in favour of IBS

* Abdominal pain that improves/worsens with defecation

* Association with stress or emotional symptoms

* Small volume of stools

Alteration in bowel habits (constipation/diarrhea) is the most consistent clinical feature in IBS. This means that a majority of people suffering from IBS have an alteration in bowel habits. The most common pattern is constipation alternating with diarrhea, usually with one of these symptoms predominating.

IBS is a clinical diagnosis that can be made without performing many tests if the patient presents with typical symptoms. However, it is recommended to perform the following tests in most patients to rule out other conditions:

* Complete blood count

* Sigmoidoscopic examination

* Stool examination for ova and parasites

* 3-week lactose-free diet

In patients >40 years, air-contrast barium enema or colonoscopy should also be performed.

Lubiprostone is used in the treatment of constipation-predominant IBS and can be prescribed to this patient.

Other options:

Option B: A centrally acting mu-opioid receptor agonist is loperamide, which is used for the treatment of diarrhea, not constipation

Option C: Encephalinase inhibitor is rececadotril, which is used for the treatment of secretory diarrhea

Option D: A 5-HT3 antagonist, such as alosetron, is used in the treatment of diarrhoea-predominant IBS.

Pearl PM2457: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

* Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine

* Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine

* Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

* Opiate - Loperamide

* 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron

* Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

* Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol

* Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone

* Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide

* 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod

* Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

Pearl PM0774: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

* Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)

* Associated with a change in stool frequency

* Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.text: 17. A 20-year-old patient is admitted to the emergency department due to breathlessness and hypotension after blunt trauma to the chest. ECG of the patient shows the following findings. Which of the following components of JVP is expected to be prominent?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows decreased voltage and electrical alternans (alternating amplitude of QRS complexes), indicative of a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. Prominent x descent in JVP is a feature of cardiac tamponade.

Cardiac tamponade is characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space leading to impairment of diastolic relaxation of the cardiac chambers. This leads to a decline in cardiac output.

Clinical presentation -

Acute cardiac tamponade develops very quickly, often in a matter of minutes, and typically presents with signs of cardiogenic shock. It is most commonly triggered by trauma, rupture of the heart or aorta, or complications from invasive cardiac procedures. In contrast, subacute cardiac tamponade progresses gradually over several days to weeks and is usually associated with pericarditis of neoplastic, uremic, or unknown (idiopathic) origin.

The characteristic signs of cardiac tamponade include:

* Tachycardia and hypotension

* Pericardial rub

* Pulsus paradoxus - this is a paradoxical reduction in the systemic blood pressure (>10 mm Hg) on inspiration. In tamponade, with an increase in venous return to the right side (during inspiration) of the heart, the interventricular septum bows towards the left ventricle (fixed total heart volume), thereby reducing left heart volume. This leads to a reduction in stroke volume and systemic blood pressure. 

* Beck's triad - this is a triad of findings in tamponade that consists of :

* hypotension

* muffled heart sounds, and 

* elevated jugular venous pressure with prominent x descent and absent y descent



* ECG shows reduced voltage and electrical alternans. Electric alternans is a specific finding caused by the anteroposterior swinging of the heart with each contraction. When the heart is nearer to the chest wall, it leads to an increased amplitude deflection on the ECG, whereas, a lower amplitude deflection is seen when the heart moves away from the chest wall.



The echocardiography shows a swinging heart sign, which is characteristic of cardiac tamponade. The pericardial pressures exceed the left ventricular diastolic filling pressures, causing the collapse of heart chambers, IVC plethora and respiratory variation in volumes and flows.



In a patient with clinical features suggestive of tamponade, the best course of action is performing pericardiocentesis, preferably carried out under echocardiographic guidance. In cases of recurrent tamponade, a small catheter may be left in place to drain subsequent collections of fluid.

Pearl PM2416: JVP waveform and the abnormalities



1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation


 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade


 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation


 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: 18. A 45-year-old male presents with classic pill rolling resting tremor and gait disturbances. The area of the brain most likely to be involved is
questions.solution:
The given case scenario suggests a diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease (PD) and the area most likely to be involved is substantia nigra, a part of the mesencephalon (midbrain).

The hallmark features of PD are degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc), reduced striatal dopamine, and intracytoplasmic proteinaceous inclusions known as Lewy bodies (containing the protein alpha synuclein).

Patients present with muscular rigidity, involuntary resting tremors of the hands, akinesia - difficulty in initiating movement - and postural instability. On examination, cog-wheel rigidity and a shuffling gait are seen. Dysphagia, speech disorders, sleep disturbances, and cognitive impairment are also seen. 

The substantia nigra is a part of the basal ganglia of the brain. It is a part of the ancillary putamen circuit. Neurons from the substantia nigra project to the caudate nucleus and putamen, known as the nigrostriatal pathway. They secrete dopamine, which is inhibitory. Since the SNc undergoes degeneration, the caudate nucleus and putamen send continuous excitatory signals to the corticospinal tract. This contributes to the rigidity seen in Parkinsonism.  

Levodopa combined with a peripheral decarboxylase inhibitor (carbidopa/benserazide) is considered the gold standard in the treatment of this disease.

Other drugs used in the treatment include dopamine agonists- Pramipexole, ropinirole, rotigotine, monoamine oxidase (MAO-B) inhibitors - Selegiline and rasagiline and catechol-O-methyl transferase (COMT) inhibitors- Tolcapone and entacapone.

questions.text: 19. A 30-year-old pregnant woman who is G2P1 in the 32nd week of gestation was found to have a blood pressure of 160/98 mmHg without proteinuria. Her BP recorded during the previous ANC visits were 144/92 mmHg and 150/96 mmHg during the 16th week and 24th week of gestation respectively. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is ____.
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is chronic hypertension because her blood pressure at the 16th week of gestation was >140/90mmHg.

* Hypertension in pregnancy is defined as a BP of >140/90 mmHg measured 2 times with at least 6-h interval.

* Also, diastolic BP is determined by the disappearance of the Korotkoff V sound (normally, in adults, we take the Korotkoff IV for measuring DBP).

Any chronic hypertensive disorder increases the risk of developing superimposed preeclampsia. This form of preeclampsia often arises sooner, manifests with increased severity, and is more likely to result in restricted fetal growth than uncomplicated preeclampsia. Other complications include abruption, preterm delivery, and increased perinatal mortality, especially in the setting of superimposed preeclampsia.

questions.text: 20. The cadaveric image shows the structures seen in the retroperitoneum. Which of the following marked structure is involved in Gerhardt’s sign?
questions.solution:
Spleen[4] is the structure involved in Gerhardt's sign. 

Pulsations of the spleen detected in the presence of splenomegaly is called Gerhardt’s sign, which is seen in aortic regurgitation.  The spleen is just lateral to the left kidney.
